Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Perdigao: Multiscale Flow Interactions in Complex Terrain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Atmospheric flow through complex terrain is difficult to simulate due to the small scales of mountains and hills and the dependence of wind on a variety of factors, such as the temperature structure of the air near the ground. This award will allow a group of researchers the opportunity to join a large field campaign in Portugal and to supplement the experiment by deploying a large number of instruments. The project should result in a data set that will be used by numerical modelers for many years to come, with impacts on understanding boundary layer flows important to wind energy, air pollution, aviation, contaminant dispersion and alpine warfare. In addition, a number of students will have the opportunity to participate in the campaign and interact with international colleagues.

The Perdigao field campaign is part of a large European effort to improve the efficiency of wind energy production. This award will bring a basic research component to the effort, with a focus on studying interactions between flows of different scales, effects of topographic and diurnal thermal forcing, valley/slope boundary layers and turbine wakes. Instrumentation provided by this project will include multiple Lidars, a Tethered Lifting System, ceilometer, radiosonde system, anemometers, and the OU CLAMPS integrated mobile profiling system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project provided high-resolution data sets of the dynamic, thermodynamic, and turbulence structure in the boundary layer inside and above Vale do Cobr?o near Perdig?o, Portugal, a narrow valley surrounded by two nearly parallel, 5 km long ridges. Given the valley orientation, southwesterly and northeasterly wind directions are perpendicular to the ridges bordering the valley. Data were collected using a mobile measurement system, CLAMPS, that includes ground-based remote sensing instruments and a near-surface monitor. CLAMPS was adapted for the international deployment  and continuously operated during the Intensive Observation Period (IOP)  from May 1, 2017 through June 15, 2017. Daily plots were generated and shared via a web interface (http://weather.ou.edu/~tybell/clamps/  and  http://weather.ou.edu/~tybell/perdigao_rhi/) with the Perdig?o science team. These plots, along with quick-look plots available in near-real time as part of the CLAMPS data system, were used to make operational decisions, such as e.g. when to release extra radio sondes or operate a tethered lifting system.  After the campaign,  CLAMPS data were processed to assess the data quality, and retrievals were applied to provide user friendly data products that are available in the Perdig?o data archive at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (https://www.eol.ucar.edu/field_projects/perdig?o) for a broad user community.  

The observations documented the local wind climatology. Inside Vale do Cobr?o winds are generally aligned with the valley and overnight southeasterly (down-valley) winds dominate which is likely caused by drainage flow. At ridge height, winds were generally perpendicular to the valley/ridges. At night, north-easterly winds were more commonly observed which were associated with northeasterly nocturnal low-level jets developing over the steep slopes between the Spanish Sierra de Gata and the Portuguese Serre de Estrela mountain ranges. These katabatic flows intensified throughout the night and moved into the Vale de Cobr?o region.

The placement and scanning strategies of multiple Doppler lidars presented an opportunity to retrieve wind profiles at four virtual towers. The profiles have a 15-min time resolution  and cover a range from 50 m to 600 m above the valley floor. The virtual tower analysis helped fill the gap between wind measurements on physical towers (up to ~ 100 m) and the height region where traditional Doppler lidar profiling scanning strategies have limitations in complex terrain. The retrieved wind profiles, allowed us to study the flow variability along Vale do Cobr?o, which was otherwise poorly documented. 

Additionally, the collected wind, temperature, and humidity profiles were used to analyze the nocturnal flow patterns at the Perdig?o site for different atmospheric stabilities. Strongly stable conditions primarily correspond to nights with a strong decrease of wind speed during the early-evening transition. This happens primarily for cases with southwesterly winds turning north during the early evening transition.  Under these conditions, down-valley winds are more prevalent inside the valley.  However, wind velocity values inside Vale de Cobr?o are generally low. During most nights, the local flow has signatures of multilayered structures and is affected by complicated meso- and micro-scale flow interactions.   

The project provided unique opportunities for training of young scientists. The project funded the research of one MS student (male) and additionally provided funds for two PhD students (1 male and 1 female) to participate in the field campaign. All three students gained valuable experience for their future careers and are now employed, or about to start, as Post-Docs or research scientists at national laboratories.
